I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The finance ministries and central banks of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
(ASEAN) have made a commitment to strengthen their financial integration as an essential step 
towards the realization of the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) by 2015. In particular, they 
plan to liberalize financial services and the capital account, and develop the capital markets. 
 
2.  To  fulfill  the  objective,  the  ASEAN  Central  Bank  Forum  (ACBF)  Task  Force  on 
Milestones  towards  ASEAN  Monetary  and  Financial  Integration  has  requested  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  support  their  Combined  Studies on  Assessing  the  Financial 
Landscape and Formulating Milestones for Monetary and Financial Integration in ASEAN. The 
combined studies aim to assess the current regulations for financial services and set milestones 
to achieve monetary and financial integration in the region. 
 
3.  ADB provided a small-scale research and development technical assistance (TA) to 
support the combined studies. As a follow-up to that TA project, ACBF has requested ADB to 
provide further support to prepare a more detailed implementation plan for the member states. 
The proposed research and development TA1 will support the combined studies in formulating a 
comprehensive  assessment  of  the  financial  sector  landscape  and  detailed  implementation 
strategies for ASEAN member countries so that the AEC’s financial integration can be achieved 
by 2015. 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  At the Bali Summit in October 2003, the ASEAN leaders declared that the AEC will be 
the goal of regional economic integration by 2020. Then, at the 12th ASEAN Summit in Cebu in 
January  2007,  the  ASEAN  leaders  affirmed  their  strong  commitment  to  accelerating  the 
establishment of the ASEAN Community by 2015. In November 2007, at the 13th ASEAN 
Summit in Singapore, the ASEAN leaders adopted the AEC Blueprint from which each ASEAN 
member country shall abide by and implement the AEC by 2015. 
 
5.  The AEC aims to establish ASEAN as a single market and production base, thereby 
making  ASEAN  more  dynamic  and  competitive.  This  will  entail  (i)  putting  in  place  new 
mechanisms and measures to strengthen the implementation of its existing economic initiatives 
and ensure the free flow of goods, services, and capital; (ii) accelerating regional integration in 
priority sectors; (iii) facilitating the movement of business persons, skilled labor, and talent; and 
(iv) strengthening the institutional mechanisms of ASEAN. 
 
6.  The AEC Blueprint, which provides a comprehensive vision of economic integration with 
a strategic schedule, states that, to achieve a free flow of financial services, ASEAN member 
countries must substantially remove restrictions in the insurance, banking, and capital market 
subsectors by 2015. For example, direct life insurance needs to be liberalized in Indonesia and 
the  Philippines;  direct  nonlife  insurance  needs  to  be  liberalized  in  Brunei  Darussalam, 
Cambodia,  Indonesia,  Malaysia,  the  Philippines,  Singapore,  and  Viet  Nam;  acceptance  of 
deposits and other repayable funds from the public needs to be liberalized in Cambodia, the Lao 
People’s Democratic Republic, and Viet Nam; trading for one’s own account or for the account 
of customers needs to be liberalized in Brunei Darussalam, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, 
Singapore, and Thailand; and asset management needs to be liberalized in Indonesia, the 
Philippines, Singapore, and Thailand.

7.  To foster the freer flow of capital, the AEC Blueprint states that member countries shall 
act to (i) remove or relax restrictions, where appropriate and possible, to facilitate the flows of 
payments and transfers for current account transactions; and (ii) remove or relax restrictions on 
capital flows, where appropriate and possible, to support foreign direct investment and initiatives 
to promote capital market development. 
 
8.  To create a strong momentum toward a more liberalized and harmonized environment in 
the financial service sector, the ASEAN finance ministries have recognized that the region 
needs a comprehensive study that maps out the current ASEAN financial landscape; analyzes 
various gaps, issues, and constraints in the integration of financial markets in ASEAN; and 
provides a detailed framework and strategy for each country. 
 
9.  The small-scale research and development TA, which was completed in November 2010, 
clarified the necessary steps to liberalize financial services and the capital account and to 
further develop the capital markets as a region. However, ASEAN central banks and the ASEAN 
Secretariat recognize that each member state requires its own detailed implementation plan. 
Thus, further ADB support is needed to prepare these plans. 
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
10.  The  small-scale  research  and  development  TA,  which  was  completed,  provided  a 
thorough and critical assessment of the current state of financial services liberalization, capital 
market development, and capital account liberalization in 10 ASEAN countries. The follow-on 
TA will provide the member states with their own implementation strategies and plans. This is 
necessary because the readiness of the member states to undertake financial and capital 
account liberalization is very different. It is necessary to customize the plans to ensure that they 
are suitable and feasible for each member state. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The  detailed  implementation  strategies  to  liberalize  financial  services  and  capital 
accounts and further develop capital markets will enable ASEAN finance ministers and central 
bank governors to better understand and initiate the liberalization process step by step based 
on specific milestones. 
 
B.   Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will: 
 
(i)  design  comprehensive  and  step-by-step  implementation  programs  for  each 
ASEAN  member  country  to  achieve  the  financial  integration  of  ASEAN,  by 
specifying  appropriate  implementation  milestones,  strategic  objectives,  and 
policy  actions  with  their  respective  timelines  as  well  as  appropriate  tools  to 
periodically monitor achievement of the milestones; different milestones will be 
developed for the advanced and emerging ASEAN economies;   
 
(ii)  identify gaps, constraints and challenges that may inhibit the financial integration 
of ASEAN, including thorough analysis of policy and regulatory issues to achieve 
integrated financial markets in ASEAN;

3
(iii)  specify the preconditions, safeguard measures, and new initiatives needed for 
ASEAN  member  countries  to  pursue  sound  and  prudent  ASEAN  financial 
integration; 
 
(iv)  assess  if  concrete  timelines  have  been  set  for  the  existing  initiatives  and  if 
integration is moving toward the set time frames, and determine if there is a need 
to accelerate the time frames to achieve the 2015 target; 
 
(v)  prioritize the complete set of initiatives, including new initiatives needed, to speed 
up and achieve the end-goals of ASEAN financial integration; and 
 
(vi)  provide best-practice models, based on other regional and country references, 
that can be adapted to the ASEAN setting. 
 
13.  The TA assumes that the ASEAN Secretariat, regulators, finance ministries, and central 
banks in all ASEAN member countries will provide support and cooperation to the consultants 
and  ADB.  Their  support  is  crucial  to  ensure  that  the  recommendations  contained  in  their 
implementation plans are effective and realistic. 
 
14.  Risks may arise from the reluctance of the governments and central banks to provide 
their  support  because  of  possible  national  opposition  to  either  liberalization  or  to  certain 
recommendations  and  milestones.  In  addition,  the  governments  may  maintain  certain 
restrictions as negotiated and agreed as “pre-agreed flexibility”, which is contemplated in the 
AEC Blueprint. Another risk may arise from an unexpected economic crisis, which would delay 
the whole process of economic integration. Although the region as a whole has weathered the 
impact of the financial crisis, it remains vulnerable to additional shocks. 
 
C.   Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at the equivalent of $725,000. The TA will be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  from  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF—other 
sources). The detailed cost estimates and a financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ADB will be the executing agency, and the Office of Regional Economic Integration will 
administer  and  implement  the  TA  in  close  consultation  with  ASEAN  member  countries, 
particularly ASEAN finance ministries and central banks. Disbursements under the TA will be 
made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010, 
amended from time to time).  
 
17.  Five  international  consultants  will  be  engaged  for  a  total  of  28  person-months  of 
international consultancy services. The international consultants’ inputs may be divided into two 
areas: (i) integration of banking sector financial services and capital account liberalization; and 
(ii) integration of nonbank financial sectors. As the study involves highly political issues, the 
ASEAN officials will need to have a high level of confidence in the international consultants. The 
consultants will be hired and engaged by ADB as individual consultants in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The outline 
of the terms of reference for the consultants is in Appendix 3. 
 
18.  The TA is expected to be completed by August 2011. The consultants will provide a draft 
of the implementation plans for member states by February 2011. After incorporating comments

4  
from member countries, the implementation plans will be revised and a regional strategy for 
coordination and implementation will be prepared. The consultants will submit the final draft to 
the ASEAN Finance and Central Bank Deputies Meeting in April 2011. If necessary, the report 
will be revised to incorporate further comments.  
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of the technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $725,000 on a grant basis 
for Assessing the Financial Landscape and Formulating Milestones for Monetary and Financial 
Integration in ASEAN, Phase 2, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require the services of international consultants, who 
will mainly assist in: (i) studying topics related to financial regulatory reform at both global and 
regional levels; (ii) delivering workshops and learning programs for mid- and high-level officials 
from  ASEAN  countries'  finance  ministries,  central  banks,  and  supervisory  authorities  on 
regulatory reform and capital flow management; and (iii) producing working papers and case 
study research outputs on macro-prudential surveillance and supervisory policy formulation.  
The consultants and resource persons will be selected and engaged in accordance with the 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). 
A.  International Principal Consultant (international, 8 person-months) 
2.  The international principal consultant’s work will be based  on the report prepared under 
the  small-scale  research  and  development  TA  for  Assessing  Financial  Landscape  and 
Formulating Milestones for Monetary and Financial Integration in ASEAN. That report assessed 
the financial policies of ASEAN member countries, the current state of financial integration, and 
the Financial Integration Milestones Blueprint. The international principal consultant will be 
engaged to:  
(i)  undertake additional research to supplement the assessment report, if necessary; 
additional research must ensure inclusion of the following points: 
(a)  the status and experiences of each country undertaking capital account 
liberalization and financial services liberalization in the bank and nonbank 
sectors; 
(b)  the  implications  and  impact  of  integrated  financial  markets  in  each 
country;  
(c)  the readiness of each country to integrate with other countries in the 
ASEAN region; 
(d)  a review of regulatory/policy issues, institutional and capacity constraints, 
and  other  factors  that  directly  impact  on  the  integration  of  financial 
markets,  particularly  of  the  bank  and  nonbank  sectors,  and  capital 
account liberalization; 
(e)  the  direction  and  speed  of  the  move  toward  financial  integration, 
particularly  in  the  bank  and  nonbank  sectors,  and  capital  account 
liberalization. A measurement framework will be designed to assess the 
progress of each ASEAN member country in implementing the various 
financial  and  central  bank  initiatives  and  determining  the  country’s 
readiness to integrate;  
(f)  new initiatives that may be needed to pursue financial integration by 2015; 
(g)  the  end-goals  of  the  ASEAN  financial  integration  (capital  account 
liberalization and financial services liberalization); 
(h)  the key milestones and timelines for liberalization of the capital account 
and financial services (bank and nonbank sectors); 
(i)  the specific initiatives required to achieve financial integration; 
(j)  appropriate  sequencing  or  mapping  of  financial  integration  measures, 
policy  actions,  and  initiatives  that  would  include  sequencing  of 
liberalization  measures  and  actions  for  capital  account  and  financial 
services liberalization (bank and nonbank sectors); 
(k)  appropriate preconditions and risk management, including safeguards (as 
necessary) and a crisis management plan;

(l)  cooperation  programs,  TA,  and  links  with  other  liberalization  and 
integration  efforts  (e.g.,  ASEAN  Capital  Markets  Forum  (ACMF) 
implementation  plan,  ASEAN  Free  Trade  Area  (AFTA),  ASEAN 
Framework Agreement on Services (AFAS), and ASEAN Investment Area 
(AIA)) that may be required for the successful financial integration of 
ASEAN by 2015; and 
(m)  an appropriate tool to periodically monitor achievements in the Financial 
Integration Milestones Blueprint; 
(ii)  prepare a draft implementation plan for each ASEAN member state that: 
(a)  estimates the gaps between the AEC Blueprint and the current state of 
and  the  existing  plans  for  capital  account  liberalization  and  financial 
sector liberalization of the member states; 
(b)  identifies and prioritizes the areas where further reforms and institutional 
changes are required in each ASEAN country; 
(c)  ensures consistency with other existing plans of various ASEAN working

(d)  formulates a scorecard to track implementation of the implementation

(iii)  coordinate the work of the financial market specialist, financial industry specialist,

(iv)  submit  a  detailed  work  plan  and  monthly  work  schedule  of  the  consultants,

(v)  provide guidance to the consultants to ensure the high quality and analytical

(vi)  coordinate  with  the  ADB  Office  of  Regional  Economic  Integration,  ASEAN

(viii)  make presentations at workshops, seminars, and conferences;  
(ix)  obtain guidance from the ASEAN Central Bank Forum and seek inputs from ADB; 
and  
(x)  perform other tasks reasonably requested by ADB, as agreed by the ASEAN

member state. The consultant will:

(ii)  provide additional research for the assessment report, if necessary;  
(iii)  estimate the gaps between the blueprints and current state of and the existing 
plans for financial market liberalization; 
(iv)  ensure  consistency  with  other  existing  plans  and  initiatives,  e.g.,  the  ACMF 
implementation plan, ASEAN 2015; 
(v)  formulate a scorecard to track implementation of the plans; 
(vi)  propose monitoring arrangements and a review mechanism;  
(vii)  propose a capacity building plan for financial market liberalization; and 
(viii)  standardize the plans for ASEAN5 to formulate plans for the BCLMV by setting a 
different scope and speed of adjustments.

facilitating frameworks, and threshold indicators for financial liberalization.  
 
15.  As the study involves highly political issues, the ASEAN Central Bank Forum, ASEAN 
Secretariat, and finance ministries must have a high level of confidence in the specialist.  
 
16.  Requirements. A university degree in economics, finance, or related fields; preferably at 
postgraduate level or its equivalent.  At least 10 years of relevant professional experience in 
related fields such as global financial regulations, international accounting standards, financial 
integration, international governance, and its related project formulation, implementation and 
coordination, especially in European countries.
